name: Justinian's Code
summary: The Corpus Juris Civilis, also known as Justinian's Code, was a comprehensive compilation of Roman law commissioned by Emperor Justinian I. It consisted of four parts: the Codex (imperial laws), the Digest (legal opinions), the Institutes (textbook), and the Novellae (new laws). This codification preserved Roman legal tradition and influenced legal systems throughout Europe for centuries.
